p: As indicated by lines three and four of Table 6 (with the current standard parameter settings), Æ. mcintoshi on its own is not able to explain the high seroprevalence found in both humans and cattle [ 17, 22], not even when including annual partial flooding of zone 1 accompanied by eclosion of part of the dormant eggs. The same can be said for Æ. ægypti, despite it being resident in the village and forest zones, although it must be understood that in this case the low values for vertical transmission were maintained.
